transcript.transcript: We're starting now. Can you talk about how things changed with the coming of the Nazis and how-- talk about the suddenness and the gradualness sort of the mixed together and how people didn't realize what was going on. Immediately, at the end of the hostilities, there was a return to relatively normal life in the little town of MiechÃ³w, where I lived in Poland. But then gradually there was an increase in the persecution by the Germans. First, the military left, and the SS came. And then with the SS came the Ukrainians and the Lithuanian who really were rather cruel towards the Jews. So there was an ever-increasing intensity of persecution, then establishment of the ghetto and ultimately the deportations or whatever other term one wants to use. I think the term "deportation" is a bit misleading. Let's cut because-- At the end of the hostilities-- that is, when Poland was defeated-- life came to a relatively normal type of situation in the little town of MiechÃ³w, where I lived. But then there was a ever-increasing intensity of persecution. First of all, the military left, the Wehrmacht, who were relatively non-punitive towards Jews or, for that matter, anyone. Then comes the civil administration, the German administration, the SS, and with them come the hired guns, so to say, the Lithuanians and the Ukrainians, who were really very vicious and cruel towards the Jews particularly. Then ghetto is formed. And first, the ghetto-- there are very inhuman conditions, true enough, but one can still go back and forth. The main point is that there is a slow increase in the nature of persecution, that there is a kind of a-- things are not all that bad. It's quite possible to survive. And after all, all along, we hope that those big powers, France, England, the United States-- any moment they're going to come into real war and quickly defeat Germany. So all along there is the notion we can somehow make it. And when the deportations, or as we called them, Ausiedlung or actions, aktionen in German, come. Then generally it is really too late to do anything. Were people-- once those things started-- tell me what those things were, and once they started, did people know what was going on on a general level? No, it was a shock to me that, when I looked into it once I was in the United States, that a reader of The New York Times knew a great deal more-- and I have copies of those newspapers-- than we did who were there because we had no way of communicating with each other. In fact, in our little town, the community hired a Pole to follow the trains so that we know where the trains are going because we didn't. And he lost track. He couldn't follow it, and we didn't know. It's a absolute fact that we did not know what was going on until after the war, really. Oh, somebody got to-- there are some people-- I have examined a lot of survivors who didn't know when they arrived in Auschwitz what was going on. So there was a general lack of knowledge. Can you talk about different conditions in Eastern and Western Europe and also how readily recognizable Jews were? For a Jew in Poland to hide was generally virtually impossible. To hide I mean to adopt a non-Jewish identity. I don't mean hiding in some closet but to be on false papers because Jews talked differently. They had a clear-cut accent, Jewish accent. They looked differently. Poland is a homogeneous society where there are no outsiders. Americans used to Italians, and Spaniards, and Norwegians. You don't have that in Poland. It's a homogeneous society. Jews were generally the only outsiders. They spoke differently. They behaved differently, and they look differently. And last not least, if they were males, they were circumcised. The only men who were circumcised were Jews, so if you had any doubts about a males identity, all you had to do is drop his pants, and you knew he was a Jew. And how is that different from other parts of Europe? In other parts of Europe, the Jews were different because the Jews were assimilated. In Poland, the assimilated group of Jews was a tiny minority. In Germany, the majority of Jews were indistinguishable from the Germans. It took all kind of research to determine that somebody was a Jew. There were lots of German Jews who just found out, thanks to Hitler, that there were Jews. You didn't have that kind of a quote unquote "problem" in Poland. You knew you were a Jew. Poles around you made it clear to you that you were a Jew, so there was no doubt about it. So Jews were assimilated in other parts of Europe. The other the level of anti-Semitism was entirely different, even in Germany. The Germans who, after all, are responsible for the genocide of the Jews were certainly not as anti-Semitic as Poles-- I don't think anyone can argue that-- so that's another factor. But the Germans behaved differently. I challenge anyone to say that the Germans were the same in Poland as they were in France, the same troops. I don't mean that they were physically different. You take a SS unit, and you station that SS unit in Krakow. And you transfer it then to Paris or Amsterdam, and they are different because they are among humans. In Poland, they were not among humans but among barbarians. Their contempt for Poles was just a little bit less than for Jews. Jews were non-human. Poles were subhuman, and so they could behave without any kind of restraint towards the Jews and towards the Poles. In Denmark, a Danish citizen annoyed with how the Germans behaved spit into the face of an SS man and got a 30-day suspended sentence. In Poland, you get a bullet between your eyes on the spot. It was a different world. The Germans behaved differently in Poland than in Western Europe. What were deportations, and what did people think they were? It was announced from time to time that there would be a deportation, that people would go to work in the East. Now, remember, the East was someplace out in Russia. It was as far removed as if somebody told you that you're going to travel to outer space, and you probably know more about outer space now than we did know what's out there in Russia. And the assumption-- at least they said you go there to work, and they directed to bring certain implements with you, and food, and whatever. It would vary from locality to locality. So there was a kind of a feeling of anxiety and the unknown. There's something terrible happening. But there was no clear-cut knowledge as to what was the purpose of it. And after all, as all human beings, the Jews of Poland did engage in some denial. One wanted to be hopeful. And again, it's very difficult to conceptualize, to think of something that is unthinkable. How do you imagine the unthinkable? Now we know, but then we didn't. It was just inconceivable to us that something that terrible could be happening. It was true in my family. My father, who was educated in Vienna and who spoke fluently German, was much more reluctant to-- We have to stop. We just ran out. We have to re-load. OK. You were talking about how difficult it was to realize what was going on, and you had just started about your father. So why don't you pick it up there? My father was educated, at least in part, in Vienna, spoke fluently German, and was really sort of familiar with the German culture. And that, in a way, was his downfall because he just could not believe that Germans would engage in something so barbaric, whereas my mother was responding more to clues that came from the environment, became very anxious, bordering and sort of almost irrational in her anxiety. She was just roaming around asking even strangers, could they somehow help in terms of doing something like for me. And my mother was indeed the one who was responsible for securing for me the place in the monastery through a woman that she barely knew. It was a woman who was selling sweets in our town, and my mother spoke to her and somehow, through that, established on a very short notice my ability to leave and go to the monastery. OK, I want to back up and ask you to define for me a ghetto as though I don't-- I don't know what a ghetto is. I don't know about the formation of the ghettos. One day, there came an announcement that there will be a Jewish quarters, which has come to be known as the ghetto, but they the Germans call it the Jewish quarters, essentially, in German. And it gave you perimeters where Jews could live, which was a tiny portion of the town. And I'm speaking of the town where I lived, but it was similarly true in other towns. And the Poles who lived in that area had to evacuate, but there was no problem because there was-- the area that the Jews left was a much wider one, so whatever Pole was displaced from the designated area for Jews-- they got much better quarters anyway, but not the other way around in terms of-- the Jews moved in a few families into one room, two families, maybe one family in one room in the beginning because the ghetto, the Jewish area, the Jewish part of town, would become smaller and smaller and smaller. But at first, it was open, so you could get in and out in certain hours. For example, a Jew could not be in the street after 7:00, but the other times you could get out and mingle, be outside. One day, there was an announcement, the ghetto is closed, and there were gates. There were walls built, and you couldn't get out. So you see, there was this ever-increasing level of persecution. I think that is the critical issue both in terms of ghetto, in terms of what happens in the ghetto. Even when they closed the ghetto, there was still enough food somehow brought in, but then, suddenly, there is less food. Suddenly, the ghetto is being made smaller. Instead of there being four blocks, now they are only two blocks. You talked about what things were punishable by death in the ghetto. What kinds of things were-- what were the punishments? What was against the law? Virtually everything that was contrary to the-- not the law because there was no law but contrary to a kind of an order given by the local German administration was punishable by death. So for example, going after the time that was forbidden for Jews-- let's say after 8:00 or after 7:00 at one point-- was punishable by death. Not wearing your armband was punishable by death. Getting outside of ghetto was punishable by death. Having white bread-- that is a fact, that I know of someone who got shot on the spot, and I hope I can tell it without reacting as I often do. That person got shot. It always gives me trouble. Tell me what it was like to live on Aryan papers, and tell me why you were able to do that. What special things made it so you were able to-- My parents, unlike virtually all of the Jews in our town-- that varied from town to town-- were assimilated. That is, they spoke very well Polish and were generally indistinguishable from the rest of the population. And certainly that applied to me as a youngster, so I could pretend that I was not a Jew with some difficulty, obviously, at first. When I came to the monastery, my familiarity with prayer, my familiarity with Catholic liturgy and so was limited, but I had some. So I could pretend. Most Jews or most boys my age would not be able to do that in Poland, that is. So that accounts for my ability to live on false papers, but that was only-- that was the beginning. One also had to have a great deal-- I can say it now in retrospect without having to be falsely modest. It required resourcefulness, courage, and an ability to sort of adapt to circumstances and perceive-- you looked at another person, and you knew that that person had a look in his or her eyes, is he a Jew? And then you had to take some action, say something. For example, if I was on a street car and a person had a look like, yeah, that kid might be a Jew, I would go to that person and ask something or maybe make some kind of a comment and a fairly aggressive comment. Like in a train, I would say, would you move your suitcase, or something like that, and that would, right away, dispel that person's suspicion because, first of all my language would be clear so that most likely he's not a Jew. And my behavior would be then different. So you see, it wasn't only the language, the appearance, but also the behavior. There was, in Poland, a kind of expression that they could recognize a Jew by sadness in his or her eyes on false papers. I remember that there was generally a fear of having a Jew live somewhere nearby because you could get punished for it, and a great many people also were anti-Semitic and approved of the persecution of Jews. That is quite inconceivable to many Poles nowadays. The new Polish generation, young people, find this offensive when one mentions that it was perfectly acceptable in Poland during World War II to see Jews tormented because it is not acceptable now. I only have a little bit left. I'm trying to think of something short. Tell me what were liquidations in the ghetto. Liquidation was a term that we used, meaning that the ghetto would be closed, that there would be-- see, one never knew. Is this the final type of deportation, or will they permit-- will some people remain? See, as a ghetto was being-- as the deportation would start, people would have certain papers that allowed them to stay. There was a hierarchy. You worked in this place. You worked in that place. Those papers were good. These ones were not. And one never knew for sure. Is this the final liquidation of that particular ghetto in this locality or not? So you could only for sure tell in retrospect. There were small-- see, the procedure that they followed that we didn't know about-- they always concentrated. They closed the smaller ghettos. Then they made bigger ghettos. Ultimately, for example, in the county where I live, there were a number of Jewish communities. It just ran out. We have to re-load. Sometime in 1942, probably early in the summer of '42, it became pretty apparent that there would be a final liquidation of the ghetto, and my mother became very anxious and just talked to anyone she could to create some type of a setting where she, and my sister, and I-- I was 14 years old at the time, not quite 14. And my mother did, through an acquaintance, arrange for a man named Godumsky-- he lived in Czestochowa-- to come to MiechÃ³w and take me to the monastery of Mogila. Now, you have to keep in mind that there was no way of communicating, and one couldn't trust-- there were some phones, but one couldn't really communicate. This lady contacted Mr. Godumsky, who didn't quite know what she wanted from him, so he came. And because we anticipated that the ghetto would be liquidated the next day, my mother left me with this lady, and I stayed there. The man came, and he did agree to take me to the monastery. But obviously, he didn't know if the monastery would accept me, and it so happened that that very day indeed, as he and I were going to the train station, there was the final liquidation of the ghetto. And as I walked with him, Jews were being driven in the streets to the trains. And I bought a ticket. I had a false document, but I didn't have to show it. And he and I didn't go together. Mr. Godumsky and I didn't go together because, if they caught me, he would be also punished. So we got on a train, and we took the train to Krakow, which is maybe just 40 miles. I think it's 60, 70 kilometers from MiechÃ³w. And then from the train station, we had to walk to the monastery, which was quite a distance at the time. And while I waited outside, he went and talked to the prior, whom he told a lie, namely that I was a converted Jew, that my family was not really Jews but converted Jews. And the prior agreed to accept me into the seminary, into the novitiate, and I, at that point, became a student, sort of say, for priesthood. And I lived there. Again, I can't be certain for how long because when I start add up all various experiences and add the amount of time they lasted, I end up with 10 years, and the war was five years. But I assume I was there more than a year, and I remained in a monastery until the day that-- I perceived one day that a priest, who was my teacher of catechism who I knew quite well, somehow suspected that I was a Jew. And the way he tipped me off-- I was, at first, not even aware of it-- was that he corrected my Polish pronunciation, and I knew that was a mistake. And he did it with a certain smirk on his face. And that night, I was so anxious about it, and Mr. Godumsky, who used to be a monk but now was in a monastery as a worker-- I told him what my feelings were, and I did hide in the organ that night. And that night, the Gestapo came and broke into my-- we called them cells, but they were nice little rooms. The monastery was beautiful, and rich, and really beautiful place. They broke in, broke the door down, and didn't find me. And then Mr. Godumsky came where I was hidden, and we sneaked out and went to another place where he had a friend whose name was Jagodzinski, with whom I communicate a great deal to the present time, who has then taken over and helped me afterwards. Tell me about some of your experiences in your time in the monastery. The monastery was really an experience where-- there were good things, too. Believe it or not, my first sexual experience occurred in the monastery, not in the monastery grounds but just outside because there were girls there from nearby who were quite interested in the boys from the monastery. There were constant fear, however, of being recognized as a Jew. One day, because I was near-sighted, I went to Krakow and acquired glasses as soon as I came in, and one of my fellow seminarians looked at me and said, Janek, that was my name, which is sort of a diminutive of Jan-- oh, you look like a Jew. And there was the last time I wore those glasses. There were many experiences that were close calls. For example, one time, one of my functions was to pick up the mail from the post office, and so I was known to everyone in the-- at that time, it was a village. Today, that village is part of the town of Krakow. But at that time, it was the village of Mogila. And everybody knew me, and they were marching a group of Jews through the village to work at the nearby German military establishment. And one of the fellows was somebody who knew me and yelled out my name. Just unthinkingly, he just yelled out, and other people looked, like what is it? So there were situations like that. Mogila wasn't all that far from our town, and sometimes I encountered people who knew me from MiechÃ³w. So there were many, many situations which were quite dangerous and required action. Tell me about the time when the head of the monastery sprinkled you excessively with holy water. The Father Kuhar, who was the prior, was really a wonderful person. At least to my recollection, he maybe was 6 foot or 6 foot 3'' and very heavy-set. He was not from Poland. He was from Yugoslavia. And he was a very benevolent person. I remember one time I was serving mass. I was the boy who-- I can't even describe it in English, even though my English is relatively well. But the Catholic terminology is still Polish in my mind. And he sprinkled me excessively with the holy water, and I could see a twinkle in his eye. And later I asked him about it, and he said with a smile-- in German, he said, [SPEAKING GERMAN], which means certain is certain, which was his way of telling me, I know it was a lie that you were baptized, but that doesn't matter. We have time for one more little, short story in the monastery. Have you got any that are short? Father Kuhar was a benevolent person who helped me, who helped my mother. My mother had black hair. Black hair meant you were a Jew. My mother was on false papers, and we had to make sure that her hair was changed to sort of more blondish look. And that required transporting her from a hiding place in Krakow, and bleaching your hair was not as simple as nowadays. And I spoke to him about it, and what he arranged-- he had a big carriage with two horses and so on. He arranged for it. He picked up my mother with the driver and took her to this place in Krakow where her hair was changed. I think we should change [? rolls. ?] If I haven't already said so, camera [? roll four, ?] [? just one up end, ?] sync tape, five is up. When we do this, [AUDIO OUT] let's do that. But wait, [INAUDIBLE], you have to put your drink down-- Yes. It's not going to be a commercial for Perrier? [LAUGHS] OK, go ahead, and-- This particular priest who recognized-- at least claimed that he recognized some kind of a speech impediment or accent that was Jewish, I believed, I was very sensitive to him, suspicious of him because I have on more than one occasion during a sermon heard them make anti-Semitic comments. For example, one time he was berating the congregation for the fact that they were doing business on Sunday, which was forbidden in Poland. Anyway, Poland was a strictly Catholic country. But people were doing it-- selling, buying things. And he was saying at one time Jews were doing that. But, thank God, we got rid of them. That was part of a sermon. So I knew how antiSemitic he was. Tell me now in general about this monastery and all the kinds of things they were involved in from resistance to-- and what happened to the head of the monastery [INAUDIBLE]. The Mogila monastery is a Cistercian monastery. It was a very-- it was established at the beginning of the 13th century. It was beautiful. It was rich. It was a place of great scholarship. It also was a place where a number of people who were in the resistance, in the Polish underground resistance, were hiding under a number of pretexts-- as workers, as priests, et cetera. And when I escaped there after they came to get me, later on I did know that Father Kuhar, the prior, a number of others were taken to Auschwitz. And, in fact, for a long time, I thought that it was because of me. It turned out it did have nothing to do with me. The Germans came and took the prior and every 10th priest and took them to Auschwitz. And then Father Kuhar was transferred to another concentration camp. He did survive after the war. And, in fact, I visited the monastery. There is a-- I brought a plaque commemorating him that is affixed in a very sort of a prominent place in the monastery. It's in Polish and in English. And I did establish an organization that is called the American Friends of Mogila Monastery to express my gratitude. When you lived there, what were your duties and what was your relationship with him [INAUDIBLE]? I was sort of like you would call an adjutant or whatever. Or his personal assistant. He trusted me particularly more than others. For example, he would give me the key to empty the collection boxes and there was a big [? large ?] church and people would put money into the collection boxes. And, in fact, to my best recollection, I was the only one that he trusted to just go in there and empty them and bring the money from it. In fact, he was, at least to me, he was an older man. I remember I would cover him up at night and I would shine his shoes, too. He was very, very kind to me. And he, as I said, he was helpful not only to me. But he was willing to take great risk to help my mother and sister. People like him and others who helped in rescues, what were the risks? In Poland, to assist a Jew, was very risky. That is, if you got apprehended, generally, the Jew was killed. Maybe taken to a camp in some situation and maybe later killed. The Poles, who were guilty of assisting Jews, were often, not always, but on many occasions, killed or sent to a camp in some villages. Their house was burned down. I know, for example, of a man who did assist my family. But that didn't have to do with our family. Mr. Kubinski whose farm was burned and his family was killed. It was not always the case, but there were quite a few Poles who were killed. How difficult was your survival from the standpoint of age? Can you talk about what it was like to be a teenager running under false papers? Oh, being a teenager had certain benefits. As a teenager, you feel that you are invulnerable, and you can do almost anything. And in reality, it also was one was more agile. I could jump from a train. I could jump from a running street car or because somebody made some move, whereas I couldn't if I was much older. There were a number of situations where I have outrun police and have outrun Germans who were shooting after me, and even with dogs. That was not-- you couldn't do it unless you were 15 or 16 years old. So that was an asset. Obviously, you might have less of a judgment in dangerous situations because you were a teenager. But by and large, I think being a teenager, considering the situation, was an asset, I believe. But obviously, I didn't have an adolescence in any normal sense of the term. Can you talk about choices that Jews would have had based on age? Like, you had more choices maybe than a 30-yearold father with two little children. Someone interviewed me once and asked a very simple question. When you left the ghetto, did you say goodbye to your mother? You know, this is a problem that a teenager will have, or a youngster. No doubt a parent would put a child into a relative safety situation but would not do it for himself or herself. My mother could not, or my father, leave and say, whatever will happen to the children will happen. But the other way around, they did it. And one of the reasons that my father didn't leave the camp later on where he was-- because he felt we needed a place where there was some sort of headquarters. Maybe that wasn't their entire reason. So parents had bigger responsibilities. Whereas as a youngster, you did what your parents told you. And somehow, you assumed that parents in their omnipotence are going to make it, whereas parents didn't have that illusion. And what were the parents chances versus the kids? [INAUDIBLE]. It had a great deal to do, I believe, with who the parents were-- adults, If you talk in terms of chance of surviving, were. Are we talking on false papers? Are we talking in hiding? Or are we talking in a camp? At all phases, there were accidental factors, and there were factors that had to do with the personality. Certainly, if you were a man, you had less chances to survive out on false papers because you would be so readily identified as a Jew by the fact that you were circumcised, whereas you couldn't absolutely prove it to a woman. And that, again, that had to do also at what point. You see, time is a tremendous factor here. It was so different late in 1942 than it was in '43. And when you get to '44, it becomes impossible. Let's finish talking about that. How different were conditions during different years over the course of the war? The chances for survival depended upon at what point in time a Jew found himself in various situations, be it on false papers, be it in hiding. being in a camp. First of all, personal resources were exhausted. For example, in our case, my mother and sister and I, even though separate, we were on false papers. Our resources were exhausted in terms of money, even. Having some in terms of having people that we could rely upon. You have some contacts. Those get exhausted. So that the longer it lasted, the less chances they'd have for survival. The same thing was true in camp. If a camp was liberated a week sooner, many more people would have survived. If the war ended six months earlier, a great many more would have survived. Remember that the Germans were so dedicated to the final solution of the Jewish question that to the last minute, they were diligently working on this project. So the more time-- it was really fighting for time. Every day, every hour mattered. Can you give me a general picture of how you survived from when you left the monastery until the end of the war? The kinds of things you did. After I escaped the monastery, I lived with this young man who was on false papers himself. He was not a Jew, but he was a underground fighter. His name, his real name was Stephan Jagodzinski, and he lives to this day. He and I lived together. He pretended that I was his nephew. And he worked-- he was repairing an organ in a large village. There was nothing wrong with the organ, but that was the cover. He was working on repairing the church organ because his father owned the factory of organs, and there was the connection. And he and I-- and I was assisting him in it. But then also, we had no funds. I had no funds anymore, no money. And we smuggled. We smuggled food from the villages surrounding Krakow to Krakow. And then we smuggled food to Warsaw, which was dangerous. And we smuggled from Warsaw a vodka, but not the real vodka, I it was called bimber, which was like moonshine. That certainly was punishable by death. In fact, I was in Warsaw smuggling bimber when the Warsaw ghetto uprising started. I remember like today we were there, Stephan and I. And then it became increasingly too dangerous, and through some contacts, we found out that one could escape to Hungary. And Hungary at that time, from what I was told, was really like paradise to us. And we did manage to escape to Hungary. And that's a long story. We had to cross the border we. Got apprehended, escaped. It was a complicated situation. And we did arrived in Hungary in 1943 sometime in the fall. My mother, sister, and I and a childhood girlfriend of mine whose father was killed in a camp. And my father knew where he was, where the girl was. Her name was Gina. And we arrived in Hungary. And we were there as Poles as false papers. But in March of '44, the Germans occupied Hungary also. So the whole same situation started again. I attempted to escape with a Jewish underground group to Romania because there was a connection to Palestine at that time but got apprehended on a border between Hungary and Romania. Hungary was occupied. Romania was not. And I was taken to a camp in Yugoslavia. And then from that camp, I was transported to a prison in Budapest. In fact, there was the prison where the famous Hannah Szenes was. She was on the same floor where I was. And I managed to escape from there with the help of friends. Tell me about the escape. The escape really occurred through assistance of a Gestapo man who was sort of half German and half Yugoslavian. And I was in a-- and I do take credit for that. I established the contact with him, and I trusted him. And which was a risk because I gave him my mother's address. And my mother was still in Budapest on false papers. And I established contact with him while we were in this prison. He could have been just playing me for a sucker, you know? But I trusted him. And it turned out he really engineered the escape. I mean, it's a long story, but it was his doing, and he engineered the escape. What was-- you said you were there at the beginning of the Warsaw ghetto uprising? Oh, no. I was only that day. I was that one day when the Warsaw ghetto uprising started, it so happened that Stefan and I were just making one of our periodic trips to pick up the moonshine. And it was, suddenly, there was tremendous amount of activity, shooting and so on. There was something going on. And we heard that there was an uprising in thee Warsaw ghetto. So you just left? Oh, we just left. We left in a great hurry. Can you talk about what you think survival is a matter of? What made a difference in survival were the personal qualities of the individuals. There were many other factors, but everything else being equal, unless you were a person who had a tremendous will to survive, who had courage, resourcefulness. And all the other factors wouldn't help. Well, sure, you needed luck, and you needed assistance of other people. But your personal qualities determined. And I am saying it not only on false papers. People who survived in camps didn't survive by accident. Everyone, I believe, every survivor, in my view, and that is maybe sort of an over-- no, I don't think it is-- is really a hero. And survivors hate that kind of a term. They avoid it because they don't want to take responsibility for their survival. And it took me a great many years in analysis to recognize that I survived thanks not only to the help of others, but thanks to my own activities, which makes me responsible for my survival. You once talked about being accused of being a survivor. The accusation of being a survivor. Survivors have been greeted with a great deal of ambivalence from the very beginning. And in particular, by fellow Jews. Because survivors, in the eyes of Jews, were suspect. How did you survive? That was the question. What kind of evil deeds did you commit in order to survive? You were somehow contaminated. You know, the Nazis said the only good Jew is a dead Jew. And in a way, after the war, immediately, I believed that was also a view of others. The dead people-- they were the victims. The survivors were somehow suspect. And you know, to this day, there are all kinds of memorials for everybody. Warsaw ghetto fighters. You have a kibbutz honoring the fighters of Warsaw ghetto. You have streets named after fighters of Warsaw ghetto. Well, who talks about survivors? What kind of what Avenue or what monument has been-- and yet survivors accomplished a great deal more than the fighters of Warsaw ghetto. So they killed a few Germans. So what? That doesn't impress me at all. I am much more impressed with a group of young men and women in Budapest who assisted people in surviving. Who risked-- the Jews who risked their lives to help other Jews survive. We ran out before you finished that last thought, so I just want you to do something that sort of answers the question who you feel are the real heroes who really risked a lot. The people who helped. During this whole, terrible period, there were Jews in addition to others who risked their lives to help other Jews. In my own situation in Budapest, for example, or in Krakow, but in Budapest particularly, there was a group of young men and women who risked their lives day in and day out to assist other Jews, who worked on false papers, who smuggled money. And they did this all to have others survive. And I am alive thanks to them. They are not celebrated as heroes. But the group in Warsaw ghetto who decided to commit a collective suicide and succeeded in the process of killing few Germans are celebrated. And I wonder why. Why that is. Why don't we celebrate survivors? Why don't we help those? Why don't we celebrate those who have assisted other Jews to survive? I think in part-- at least, that's my own answer to this question-- is that we have sort of identified with this militaristic age where it really matters not if you preserve life but if you destroy the enemy. When I first went to Yad Vashem many years ago, and as I walked in there, which isn't true anymore, the first thing you saw was a bigger than life picture of some Jews with guns. As if this was the big deal. That didn't matter. It didn't ever impress me that some Jew during the war years managed to get a gun. That didn't accomplish anything. So you killed one Germans, or two, or three. So what? I am much more impressed with the fact that someone had the strength, the courage to survive. The courage to endure. The courage to endure. That really is what matters. Do you think there are close calls that you had that you think that we should talk about? Oh, I had a great many close calls. And one of the sort of funny part of it is that in Europe, there was a great deal of literature on Indian law written by a German called Karl May who never was in America, who never saw an Indian. Who, in fact, wrote his books in prison. But we lived on those books as kids. And I knew them and read them. And let me tell you, reading those books helped me in a number of times to survive. When we were crossing the border from Poland into Slovakia, we suddenly-- and it was pitch dark, and we had guides. And suddenly, there were lights, dogs, and shots. And we-- I first ran, you know, it was my mother, sister, and this girl Gina. And obviously, I could run the fastest. But then I realized my mother and sister would be caught. And I could hear from a distance that there were also dogs there. And you know, what I have read about Indian law and all that. I shoved my mother-- there was a river nearby-- as she approached, and my sister and Gina, and then jumped after them, and walked against the stream. Forced them. My mother was terrified. And that really saved our life at that particular time. Then we did hide, and the guides who escaped-- they were mountain people from Poland-- they came and found us. Now, these are strange things. And there were many other similar situations where they're just, in a way, bizarre in nature. But one relied upon one's resourcefulness, really. That I have to come back to the same term. One could not survive without wanting to live no matter what, and also being resourceful. You told the story of the Gestapo asking for volunteers for execution [INAUDIBLE]. Yes, I was in Szeged, and they told us-- it was at a makeshift prison, a Gestapo prison. And three of our group escaped. And they came in. In fact, I see it like before my eyes today. The chief of Gestapo came in with his white gloves and stood there heading with the white gloves and the bars asking-- we were beaten before quite a bit, but we were lined up and standing-- asking for volunteers for execution. And a friend of mine whose name I remember to this day-- many names I don't remember-- was Samek, he volunteered first. He was depressed, and he really didn't want to live. I volunteered second, but I assure you, it wasn't because I wanted to die. It was because I believed that they would not execute those who volunteered. It was too simple. They wouldn't do the normal things who volunteered for execution would, after all, be the one who was not an escape risk. And I was right. And tell me about the letter that the man brought you from your father when he was in Treblinka. When I was in the monastery, one day, I was told that somebody is at the gate who was asking for me. And as I approached there, I could see a young man who clearly looked Jewish. And he handed me a letter. And it was a letter from my father, who was in the-- which was the airport. This was the name of the camp, really, but it was called the airport. Jews worked on that airport, and my father said, you have to help this young man. He has to survive. And they were trying to get some papers for him, and he was going to have a contact. Anyway, I did hide him in my cell, in my room. I brought him food, and I did keep him for a few days. I can't tell you exactly how long, but not very long. And he did tell me that he escaped from Treblinka and described to me what he did see and how he escaped. And for many years, I forgot it. I remembered it in my analysis. And incidentally, he did not survive. There's a relative of his that did survive, and I did get in touch with her. I know about her. She lives in Switzerland, but he did not survive. Do you feel that people would do anything at all in order to survive? No. No. I think that in terms-- I think that people showed conscience. Now, what I did want to say is when I was arrested by the Gestapo and I was in this camp, my mother who was in Budapest at the time. Was approached and that if she'd become an informer, they would rescue me. They would get me, which wasn't incidentally true. But it was a setup. She was on false papers. And she refused. And I'm proud of it. Thanks.

organizations.name: TheirStory
organizations.description: TheirStory is a web-based interviewing and storytelling platform that helps families and organizations streamline the process of collecting and making more accessible the audiovisual oral histories of their communities. For example, the Jewish Historical Society of the Upper Midwest uses TheirStory to memorialize the stories -- through both in-person and remote interviews -- of a congregation in Minnesota who lost their synagogue due to arson. Other institutions who use TheirStory include the Jewish Agency for Israel in Jerusalem, the Five Oaks Museum in Portland, OR, and the New Roots Charter School in Ithaca, NY.

organizations.name: Los Angeles Public Library
organizations.description: The Los Angeles Public Library provides free and easy access to information, ideas, books and technology that enrich, educate and empower every individual in our city's diverse communities.

lines.line: # Introduction and Initial Reflections

> The interview begins, setting the context of the Second World War and the gradual increase in persecution. The reminiscences focus on the changes in Poland with the arrival of the Nazis, and how people were often unaware of the circumstances developing around them.
** Introduction, World War II, persecution, Poland, Nazis, unawareness **
keywords: ** Introduction, World War II, persecution, Poland, Nazis, unawareness **

metadata.synopsis: The interview begins, setting the context of the Second World War and the gradual increase in persecution. The reminiscences focus on the changes in Poland with the arrival of the Nazis, and how people were often unaware of the circumstances developing around them.
metadata.keywords: Introduction, World War II, persecution, Poland, Nazis, unawareness

lines.line: # Life in Miechów Post-Hostilities

> An in-depth look at how life returned to a semblance of normalcy in Miechów before the persecution intensifies with the arrival of the SS, Ukrainians, and Lithuanians, leading to the formation of ghettos.
** Miechów, normalcy, SS, Ukrainians, Lithuanians, ghettos **
keywords: ** Miechów, normalcy, SS, Ukrainians, Lithuanians, ghettos **

metadata.keywords: Miechów, normalcy, SS, Ukrainians, Lithuanians, ghettos

lines.line: # Increasing Persecution and Formation of Ghettos
> Detailing the intensifying persecution and the eventual establishment of ghettos. The chapter narrates the Jewish hope for liberation by allied powers and their misunderstanding of 'deportations'.
** persecution, ghettos, deportations, Jewish hope, allied powers **
keywords: ** persecution, ghettos, deportations, Jewish hope, allied powers **

lines.line: # Understanding the Deportations
> Reflections on the shock and disbelief among Jews regarding deportations. The chapter covers the misinformation about destinations and the community's attempts at gaining knowledge.
** deportations, misinformation, shock, disbelief **

metadata.title: Understanding the Deportations
metadata.synopsis: Reflections on the shock and disbelief among Jews regarding deportations. The chapter covers the misinformation about destinations and the community's attempts at gaining knowledge.

lines.line: # Conditions in Eastern vs. Western Europe
> A comparison of conditions for Jews in Eastern and Western Europe, illustrating the impossibility for Jews in Poland to hide due to cultural and physical differences.
** Eastern Europe, Western Europe, hiding, cultural differences **
keywords: ** Eastern Europe, Western Europe, hiding, cultural differences **

metadata.title: Conditions in Eastern vs. Western Europe
metadata.synopsis: A comparison of conditions for Jews in Eastern and Western Europe, illustrating the impossibility for Jews in Poland to hide due to cultural and physical differences.
metadata.keywords: Eastern Europe, Western Europe, hiding, cultural differences

lines.line: # Daily Life and Restrictions in the Ghettos
> Describes the oppressive restrictions within the ghettos, punishable offenses, and the struggle for food. The narrative highlights the cruel and arbitrary nature of Nazi-enforced rules.
** ghettos, restrictions, punishments, food shortages **

metadata.title: Daily Life and Restrictions in the Ghettos
metadata.synopsis: Describes the oppressive restrictions within the ghettos, punishable offenses, and the struggle for food. The narrative highlights the cruel and arbitrary nature of Nazi-enforced rules.

lines.line: # Living on Aryan Papers
> An account of living under false identities—'Aryan Papers'—showcasing the adaptation and subterfuge necessary for survival, including language, behavior, and external perceptions.
** Aryan Papers, false identity, adaptation, survival **
keywords: ** Aryan Papers, false identity, adaptation, survival **

metadata.title: Living on Aryan Papers
metadata.synopsis: An account of living under false identities—'Aryan Papers'—showcasing the adaptation and subterfuge necessary for survival, including language, behavior, and external perceptions.

lines.line: # Liquidations of the Ghettos
> Explanation of the term 'liquidation' in the context of ghettos, the uncertainty of these actions, and the finality that many Jews faced during Nazi operations.
** liquidation, ghettos, deportation, Nazi operations **

metadata.title: Liquidations of the Ghettos
metadata.synopsis: Explanation of the term 'liquidation' in the context of ghettos, the uncertainty of these actions, and the finality that many Jews faced during Nazi operations.

lines.line: # Securing Safety: Escape to the Monastery
> A personal narrative about escaping to a monastery for safety. A detailed account of how families attempted to use personal connections and quick thinking to evade deportation.
** escape, monastery, safety, personal connections **

metadata.title: Securing Safety: Escape to the Monastery
metadata.synopsis: A personal narrative about escaping to a monastery for safety. A detailed account of how families attempted to use personal connections and quick thinking to evade deportation.

lines.line: # Life and Close Calls in the Monastery
> Life within the monastery, close calls with exposure, and interactions with benevolent figures like Father Kuhar who helped disguise identities.
** monastery, close calls, Father Kuhar, disguise **

> Exploration of the risks non-Jews faced when helping Jews, and the bravery required to act amidst such danger, highlighted by personal anecdotes of those who assisted.
** risks, assistance, bravery, non-Jews **

metadata.title: Risks in Assisting Jews
metadata.synopsis: Exploration of the risks non-Jews faced when helping Jews, and the bravery required to act amidst such danger, highlighted by personal anecdotes of those who assisted.

lines.line: # Adolescence in Turmoil: Pros and Cons
> Discusses the advantages and disadvantages of being a teenager during tumultuous times. Emphasizes agility and risk-taking inherent in youth as both asset and liability.
** adolescence, advantage, agility, risk-taking **

metadata.title: Adolescence in Turmoil: Pros and Cons
metadata.synopsis: Discusses the advantages and disadvantages of being a teenager during tumultuous times. Emphasizes agility and risk-taking inherent in youth as both asset and liability.

lines.line: # Escaping to Hungary and Beyond
> Narrates the dangerous journey to Hungary, highlighting the survival tactics and the complex dynamics of escaping occupied areas, including the attempt to move to Romania.
** escape, Hungary, Romania, survival tactics **

metadata.title: Escaping to Hungary and Beyond
metadata.synopsis: Narrates the dangerous journey to Hungary, highlighting the survival tactics and the complex dynamics of escaping occupied areas, including the attempt to move to Romania.

lines.line: # Understanding Survival and Responsibility
> Reflecting upon survival during the Holocaust, considering the factors of personal will, resourcefulness, and the controversial 'accusation' of surviving.
** survival, Holocaust, resourcefulness, responsibility **

metadata.title: Understanding Survival and Responsibility
metadata.synopsis: Reflecting upon survival during the Holocaust, considering the factors of personal will, resourcefulness, and the controversial 'accusation' of surviving.

lines.line: # Remembering and Celebrating Heroes
> Contemplation on the unsung heroes of the Holocaust, emphasizing the importance of acknowledging those who helped others survive rather than glorifying militaristic feats.
** heroes, survival, acknowledgment, unsung **

metadata.title: Remembering and Celebrating Heroes
metadata.synopsis: Contemplation on the unsung heroes of the Holocaust, emphasizing the importance of acknowledging those who helped others survive rather than glorifying militaristic feats.

story.title: Dr. Emanuel Tanay (February 4th, 1992)
story.description: The interview focuses on the shifting atmosphere in Poland with the rise of the Nazi regime, exemplified by the narrator's personal experiences. Initially, life in Miechów seemed to return to normal after hostilities, but persecution steadily intensified, marked by the establishment of ghettos and deportations. The narrator describes how Jewish identity was inescapable in Poland, complicating efforts to hide or assimilate, unlike in more diverse parts of Europe. A significant portion of the narrative involves the narrator’s time in a monastery and subsequent escape, emphasizing the resourcefulness, courage, and external help required to survive. The interview also highlights the vilification of survivors and the unrecognized heroism of those who facilitated Jewish survival during the war.
